# Introduction to Git

## Git VS GitHub

* git provides version control, which creates a better workflow
* GitHub provides central repository and features

## Why should you want version control?

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

## Why you shouldn't?

**Large**, *binary* files

### Three stages of git

1. working
1. staging
1. committing (to history)

### The first three commands you should know

1. git init
1. git add .
1. git commit -m "message"

### Configuration steps you may run once and forget

```
git config --global user.name "Moe Szyslak"
git config --gloabl user.email "moe@moesbar.com"
```

### The next three commands you should know, with GitHub

1. git clone
1. git pull
1. git push

## Create a GitHub account

[educational account](https://education.github.com/ "free student account")

### Clone some repositories

1. [class repo][class-repo]
1. [basic training][git-training]

### Create a new repo

* You'll want a private repository for class
* Add Cole^2 (couthcommander and colemanrharris) as collaborators (see 4th assignment)

### Additional GitHub features

* GitHub pages
    * Nick wrote a [tutorial][github-pages]
* Issues
* Wiki

### Topics left undiscussed

* branching
* merging
* forking
* pull requests
* plenty more, found [here][git-lecture].
